lexicalItems.sourceContext: The Romans, who once controlled areas of Europe, North Africa and Asia Minor, adopted the construction techniques of other civilizations to build tunnels in their territories.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To start to use the building methods of other cultures.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Áp dụng các kỹ thuật xây dựng.

phase3Production.content: The company decided to adopt the construction techniques used by their successful competitor.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...adopted the construction techniques of other civilizations...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The society, culture, and way of life of a particular area.

phase3Production.content: The museum has exhibits from many ancient civilizations around the world.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...to build tunnels that provided a reliable supply of water to human settlements in dry areas.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Một 'nguồn cung cấp' (supply) 'nước' (of water) 'đáng tin cậy' (reliable).

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A dependable and consistent source of water.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Nguồn cung cấp nước đáng tin cậy.

phase3Production.content: A reliable supply of water is essential for any town or city.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...a reliable supply of water to human settlements in dry areas.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Places where people have come to live and build their homes.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Các khu định cư của con người.

phase3Production.content: Archaeologists have discovered the remains of ancient human settlements in this valley.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: In the early first millennium BCE, they introduced the qanat method of tunnel construction...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The period of time from the year 1000 BC to 1 BC.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Thiên niên kỷ thứ nhất trước Công nguyên.

phase3Production.content: Many great empires rose and fell during the first millennium BCE.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...to ensure that the tunnel kept to its route...

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Đường hầm 'giữ đúng' (kept to) 'tuyến đường' (its route) của nó.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To stay on the intended path or course.

phase3Production.content: Despite the storm, the ship's captain ensured that the vessel kept to its route.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...and then digging vertical shafts down into the ground at regular intervals.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Excavating deep, narrow passages that go straight down into the earth.

phase3Production.content: The miners started by digging a vertical shaft to reach the coal seam.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...digging vertical shafts down into the ground at regular intervals.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Repeated with the same amount of time or space between each one.

phase3Production.content: The bus stops at regular intervals along the main road.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: The excavated soil was taken up to the surface using the shafts...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Earth and rock that has been removed from the ground by digging.

phase3Production.content: The excavated soil was piled high next to the construction site.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...which also provided ventilation during the work.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Supplied a means for fresh air to enter and move around a space.

phase3Production.content: The open windows provided natural ventilation for the room.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: They later passed on their knowledge to the Romans...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To give one's skills or information to a younger generation or another group.

phase3Production.content: The master craftsman passed on his knowledge to his apprentice.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: The shafts were equipped with handholds and footholds to help those climbing in and out of them...

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Được 'trang bị' (equipped with) 'chỗ bám tay' (handholds) 'và' (and) 'chỗ đặt chân' (footholds).

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Fitted with places to put one's hands and feet to make climbing easier.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Được trang bị chỗ bám tay và chỗ đặt chân.

phase3Production.content: The climbing wall was equipped with colourful handholds and footholds.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...Romans hung a plumb line from a rod placed across the top of each shaft...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To suspend a cord with a weight at the bottom to determine verticality.

phase3Production.content: The builder hung a plumb line to ensure the wall was perfectly straight.

lexicalItems.targetLexeme: determine the slope of the tunnel
lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...and to determine the slope of the tunnel.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To find out or establish the gradient or incline of the tunnel.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Xác định độ dốc của đường hầm.

phase3Production.content: Engineers used precise instruments to determine the slope of the new railway line.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: The 5.6-kilometer-long Claudius tunnel, built in 41 CE to drain the Fucine Lake in central Italy...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To remove the water from a lake, typically by channeling it away.

phase3Production.content: The project's goal was to drain the lake and create new farmland.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...a second method of tunnel construction appeared called the counter-excavation method, in which the tunnel was constructed from both ends.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A technique where a tunnel is built by digging from both opposite ends towards the middle.

phase3Production.content: The Channel Tunnel was built using a sophisticated counter-excavation method.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...when the qanat method was not a practical alternative.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Không phải là 'một giải pháp thay thế' (an alternative) 'khả thi' (practical).

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Not a feasible or sensible option.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Không phải là một giải pháp thay thế khả thi.

phase3Production.content: Walking to the city from here is not a practical alternative; it's too far.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: This method required greater planning and advanced knowledge of surveying, mathematics and geometry...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A high level of understanding of the science of measuring land and distances.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Kiến thức trắc địa nâng cao.

phase3Production.content: Building the pyramids required an advanced knowledge of surveying and astronomy.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...as both ends of a tunnel had to meet correctly at the center of the mountain.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To join together at the right point with precision.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Gặp nhau một cách chính xác.

phase3Production.content: It was a feat of engineering for the two halves of the bridge to meet correctly in the middle.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Adjustments to the direction of the tunnel also had to be made whenever builders encountered geological problems...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To face or experience difficulties related to the earth's physical structure and substance.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Gặp phải các vấn đề địa chất.

phase3Production.content: The miners encountered geological problems such as underground water and unstable rock.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...or when it deviated from its set path.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Khi nó 'lệch khỏi' (deviated from) 'lộ trình' (path) 'đã định' (set).

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To depart or stray from the established or intended course.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Lệch khỏi lộ trình đã định.

phase3Production.content: The pilot deviated from the set path to avoid the storm.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: They constantly checked the tunnel’s advancing direction...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To monitor or examine something continuously or very frequently.

phase3Production.content: She constantly checked her phone for new messages.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...checked the tunnel’s advancing direction, for example, by looking back at the light that penetrated through the tunnel mouth...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The direction in which something is moving forward.

phase3Production.content: The army's advancing direction was towards the capital city.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...the light that penetrated through the tunnel mouth...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To pass into or through something.

phase3Production.content: The sunlight penetrated through the thick clouds.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...and made corrections whenever necessary.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To make changes to something in order to make it accurate or right.

phase3Production.content: The editor read the manuscript and made corrections to the grammar.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Large deviations could happen, and they could result in one end of the tunnel not being usable.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Significant departures from an established course or standard.

phase3Production.content: Any large deviations from the plan must be approved by the manager.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: An inscription written on the side of a 428-meter tunnel, built by the Romans...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Words inscribed, as on a monument or in a book.

phase3Production.content: An inscription on the statue revealed the date it was made.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...as part of the Saldae aqueduct system in modern-day Algeria...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A network of artificial channels for conveying water, typically in the form of a bridge across a valley or other gap.

phase3Production.content: The ancient city was supplied with water by a complex aqueduct system.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...describes how the two teams of builders missed each other in the mountain...

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Đã 'lệch nhau/không gặp nhau' (missed each other).

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To fail to meet or connect at the intended point.

phase3Production.content: The two tunneling teams miscalculated and missed each other by several meters.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...and how the later construction of a lateral link between both corridors corrected the initial error.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A connecting passage that runs sideways.

phase3Production.content: They built a lateral link to connect the two main tunnels.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...corrected the initial error.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To fix the first mistake that was made.

phase3Production.content: The accountant found and corrected the initial error in the financial report.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Remarkably, a modern road still uses this tunnel today. Tunnels were also built for mineral extraction.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The process of removing valuable minerals from the earth.

phase3Production.content: Mineral extraction is a major industry in this region.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Miners would locate a mineral vein and then pursue it with shafts and tunnels underground.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To find the location of a long, narrow deposit of a mineral in rock.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Xác định vị trí một vỉa khoáng sản.

phase3Production.content: The prospectors were hoping to locate a mineral vein rich in silver.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: When the sole purpose of a tunnel was mineral extraction, construction required less planning...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The one and only reason for something.

phase3Production.content: The sole purpose of his visit was to sign the contract.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Roman tunnel projects were carefully planned and carried out.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Được 'lên kế hoạch' (planned) 'và' (and) 'thực hiện' (carried out) 'một cách cẩn thận' (carefully).

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To be meticulously organized and executed.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Được lên kế hoạch và thực hiện cẩn thận.

phase3Production.content: The military operation was carefully planned and carried out.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: The qanat construction method was usually faster than the counter-excavation method as it was more straightforward.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Uncomplicated and easy to do or understand.

phase3Production.content: The instructions for assembling the furniture were surprisingly straightforward.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: When the rock was hard, the Romans employed a technique called fire quenching...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To make use of a particular method or skill.

phase3Production.content: The artist employed a unique technique to create texture in his paintings.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...a technique called fire quenching which consisted of heating the rock with fire, and then suddenly cooling it with cold water so that it would crack.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Kỹ thuật 'tôi (kim loại) bằng lửa' (fire quenching) - ở đây là làm nứt đá.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A method of breaking rock by heating it with fire and then rapidly cooling it with water to cause it to fracture.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Làm nguội bằng lửa (để phá đá).

phase3Production.content: Ancient miners used fire quenching to break up large rocks.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Progress through hard rock could be very slow, and it was not uncommon for tunnels to take years, if not decades, to be built.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Forward movement or advancement through solid, difficult-to-break rock.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Sự tiến triển qua đá cứng.

phase3Production.content: Progress through the hard rock was slow and required heavy machinery.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...it was not uncommon for tunnels to take years, if not decades, to be built.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: 'Không phải là không phổ biến' (not uncommon) -> khá phổ biến.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Fairly common; happening often.

phase3Production.content: It was not uncommon for families in that era to have ten or more children.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...to take years, if not decades, to be built.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: 'Nếu không muốn nói là hàng thập kỷ' (if not decades).

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Used to suggest that the actual number or amount may be even larger or more extreme than the one just mentioned.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Nếu không muốn nói là hàng thập kỷ.

phase3Production.content: The project will take months, if not years, to complete.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Construction marks left on a Roman tunnel in Bologna show that the rate of advance through solid rock was 30 centimeters per day.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Scratches, lines, or other signs left on a structure during the process of building it.

phase3Production.content: Archaeologists studied the construction marks on the ancient wall to understand how it was built.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...the rate of advance through solid rock was 30 centimeters per day.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The speed at which progress is made.

phase3Production.content: The army's rate of advance was slowed by the difficult terrain.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: In contrast, the rate of advance of the Claudius tunnel can be calculated at 1.4 meters per day.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Used to show that something is different from what has just been said.

phase3Production.content: The north of the country is very industrial. In contrast, the south is mainly agricultural.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Most tunnels had inscriptions showing the names of patrons who ordered construction...

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Những 'người bảo trợ' (patrons) 'đã ra lệnh' (who ordered) 'xây dựng' (construction).

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Wealthy or influential people who commissioned and paid for the building project.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Những người bảo trợ đã ra lệnh xây dựng.

phase3Production.content: The inscription names the patrons who ordered the construction of the temple.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...built to divert the floodwater threatening the harbor of the ancient city...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To cause floodwater to change course or turn from its original direction.

phase3Production.content: A new canal was built to divert the floodwater away from the town.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...divert the floodwater threatening the harbor of the ancient city...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Posing a danger to the port.

phase3Production.content: The rising sea level is threatening the historic harbor.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...had inscriptions on the entrance, still visible today, that also indicate that the tunnel was started in 69 CE and was completed in 81 CE.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Can still be seen in the present time.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Vẫn còn nhìn thấy ngày nay.

phase3Production.content: The ancient Roman road is still visible today in some parts of the countryside.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...the tunnel was started in 69 CE and was completed in 81 CE.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Was finished in a particular year.

phase3Production.content: The Eiffel Tower was completed in 1889.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...relying on estimation, inherited techniques and personal experience.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Knowledge or skill that you get from doing, seeing, or feeling things yourself.

phase3Production.content: His advice was based on years of personal experience in the industry.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...give descriptions and representations of ancient Roman ships...

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Những 'mô tả' (descriptions) và 'hình ảnh đại diện' (representations).

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Written accounts and pictures or models of something.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Các mô tả và hình ảnh đại diện.

phase3Production.content: The museum contains detailed descriptions and representations of life in the 18th century.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...including the sails and rigging.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The sails and the system of ropes, cables, or chains employed to support a ship's masts and control its sails.

phase3Production.content: The storm was so strong that it damaged the ship's sails and rigging.

lexicalItems.targetLexeme: first centuries of the current era
lexicalItems.sourceContext: Then in the first centuries of the current era, Mediterranean shipbuilders shifted to another shipbuilding method...

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Những 'thế kỷ' (centuries) 'đầu tiên' (first) 'của' (of) 'Công nguyên' (the current era).

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The period from approximately 1 CE to 300 CE.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Những thế kỷ đầu Công nguyên.

phase3Production.content: The Roman Empire was at its peak during the first centuries of the current era.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...another shipbuilding method, still in use today...

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: 'Vẫn được sử dụng' (still in use) 'ngày nay' (today).

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Continuing to be used in the present time.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Vẫn còn được sử dụng ngày nay.

phase3Production.content: Amazingly, some Roman aqueducts are still in use today.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...and then proceeding with the hull and the other components of the ship.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The different parts that make up a ship.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Các bộ phận của con tàu.

phase3Production.content: The engine is one of the most important components of the ship.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: The ancient Romans built large merchant ships and warships...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Ships used for trade and transporting goods.

phase3Production.content: The harbor was full of merchant ships from all over the world.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Warships used both wind (sails) and human power (oarsmen)...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Physical strength provided by people, especially for propulsion.

phase3Production.content: Before the invention of the steam engine, many machines were run by human power.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: The ‘trireme’ was the dominant warship from the 7th to 4th century BCE.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Most important, powerful, or influential.

phase3Production.content: English is the dominant language in international business.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: They had a wider hull, double planking and a solid interior for added stability.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A method of constructing a ship's hull with two layers of planks.

phase3Production.content: The ship's hull was reinforced with double planking to make it stronger.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: They had a wider hull, double planking and a solid interior for added stability.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The inside part of the ship that is firm and stable, not hollow.

phase3Production.content: The statue had a solid interior, making it very heavy.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: To assist them, music would be played on an instrument, and oars would then keep time with this.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To maintain the same rhythm or tempo as something else.

phase3Production.content: The dancers moved their feet to keep time with the music.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...and agricultural products (e.g. grain from Egypt’s Nile valley).

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Goods produced by farming, such as crops and livestock.

phase3Production.content: The market sells a wide variety of fresh agricultural products.

lexicalItems.targetLexeme: Goods from all over the world
lexicalItems.sourceContext: Goods from all over the world would come to the city...

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: 'Hàng hóa' (Goods) 'từ khắp nơi trên thế giới' (from all over the world).

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Products and merchandise from many different countries.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Hàng hóa từ khắp nơi trên thế giới.

phase3Production.content: The port city was a bustling hub for goods from all over the world.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...the gigantic port of Ostia situated at the mouth of the Tiber River.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The place where a river enters the sea.

phase3Production.content: The ancient city was built at the mouth of the river for easy access to the sea.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: The time of travel along the many sailing routes could vary widely.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The paths that ships regularly take across the sea.

phase3Production.content: Ancient sailors followed established sailing routes to trade with distant lands.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...but on experience, local knowledge and observation of natural phenomena.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Knowledge that is held and used by people in a particular community or area.

phase3Production.content: The fishermen relied on local knowledge of the tides and currents.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...seamen in the Mediterranean often had the mainland or islands in sight...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A large continuous extent of land that includes the greater part of a country or continent, not including islands.

phase3Production.content: After a week on the island, we returned to the mainland.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...which was used to pierce the timber hulls...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To go into or through something, making a hole in it with a sharp point.

phase3Production.content: The needle was sharp enough to pierce the thick leather.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...or break the oars of enemy vessels.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A pole with a flat blade at one end, used for rowing a boat.

phase3Production.content: The crew dipped their oars into the water and began to row.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Eventually, Rome’s navy became the largest and most powerful in the Mediterranean...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: In the end, especially after a long delay, dispute, or series of problems.

phase3Production.content: After many attempts, he eventually succeeded in passing his driving test.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Their V-shaped hull was deep underwater...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Far below the surface of the water.

phase3Production.content: The shipwreck lies deep underwater on the ocean floor.

lexicalItems.targetLexeme: sail too close to the coast
lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...meaning that they could not sail too close to the coast.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: 'Đi thuyền' (sail) 'quá gần' (too close) 'bờ biển' (to the coast).

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To navigate a boat very near to the land beside the sea.

phase3Production.content: Large ships cannot sail too close to the coast because the water is too shallow.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...and a small triangular sail at the bow.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A sail shaped like a triangle.

phase3Production.content: The small boat was easily identifiable by its bright red triangular sail.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: To assist them, music would be played on an instrument...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: In order to help them.

phase3Production.content: A guide was provided to assist them with the museum tour.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: When weather conditions were not good...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The state of the atmosphere at a place and time as regards heat, dryness, sunshine, wind, rain, etc.

phase3Production.content: The flight was cancelled due to poor weather conditions.
